txt.en: 'It... is empty!'
'What have you done with it, Zôreth?'
'Hearken to me, my brethren!'
'This day we shed the name given to us by the Dark Lord in mockery of my forefathers!'
'We are the Firehorns, proud and unbroken, and Manthríf will be ours once more! That is the oath I now swear!'
'Yes, Spakorth?'
'These traitors and thieves: Gimli, Spakorth, and [placeholder] are banished from our spire -- the Oath-taker's Horn!'
'You have a keen eye, old friend, but we shall not speak of that yet.'
'That is the only mercy I will offer you now! Begone!'
'That is a matter to be discussed in private. Gimli and [placeholder], will you join us?'
'For many years, even before the fall of Khazad-dûm, the dwarves dwelt in the Lonely Mountain.'
'Some of those that once lived in exile now dwell in the Blue Mountains, but King Dáin and his folk again live within the Lonely Mountain.'
'When Khazad-dûm was lost, my folk fled to the Lonely Mountain and rebuilt our kingdom within it.'
'It is a tale of dwarves, dragons, and days long ago. Do you wish me to tell it, King Váskmun?'
'What did you say?!'
'There sat the first King under the Mountain, and for many years, my people prospered.'
'Very well! I shall tell it as best I can.'
'Silence!'
'But it was not fated to remain so....'
'Dolgráth the Battle-hungry will taste of your flesh, witch.'
'You need only decide how long you will suffer!'
'A great dragon, Smaug, brought ruin upon the Lonely Mountain and dwelt within the deserted halls of my people.'
'My folk were cursed with misfortune for many years, and even the Orcs mocked us!'
'But then came the day that Thorin Oakenshield set out to reclaim Erebor and slay Smaug!'
'With only thirteen dwarves, a hobbit, and an old grey wizard, Smaug was vanquished and Erebor reclaimed!'
'Hah! We did a lot more than stand against them. I slew forty-two Orcs with my own axe at the Hornburg!'
'Alas! With Erebor no longer guarded by a dragon, great armies gathered to lay claim to its treasures.'
'Enough! I yield!'
'Although we did not begin the battle as allies, Men and Elves alike aided my folk in repelling the Orcs of the North.'
'So this is what those long years of wearing Manthríf in the dungeons did to you?'
'We learned in the years that followed that a great evil had laid hidden just beyond our lands.'
'Oh yes, I know about that. Always it was given, yet always it was taken.'
'Bolg, son of the hated Azog, was defeated and the Lonely Mountain was ours once more!'
'Look what it has reduced you to, Váskmun.'
'That is the tale, King Váskmun!'
'You will destroy your own people. The Dark Lord himself would delight in the irony!'
Bahahaha! What a king you are, Váskmun.'
The fell spirit flees into the higher reaches of Lûghash!
Doom of the Stout-axes! The last of your line!'
Spakorth whispers something to King Greytooth...
'I pity you.'
'Your misbegotten kind are free, then. I release them!'
'I would trade them all for you... or at least that key of yours.'
'For it alone can open this coffer I claimed from the vaults of the Dark Lord.'
'It is sealed with enchantments of the Elder Days, but the Ring of Power you seek lies within.'
'Alas, it will not be yours, Váskmun. It will remain in my keeping here at Lûghash.'
'It is not to merely be shown, King Greytooth, but it is a gift in honour of your return!
'That is the bargain. Their freedom for the key, or naught at all!'
'My trusted friends, old and new, you are the first with whom I will share this secret.'
'Behold! Dolgráth the Battle-hungry!'
'Exile? I do not understand.'
'What say you, Váskmun?'
'Of course!'
'Do I?'
'And what a tale it was! I am honoured to have heard it!'
'Your dwarf friend told an interesting tale, Váskmun. One that I know well.'
'Do not worry, I have not forgotten you, Sversting! What did you wish to show me?'
'It happened as he told it, save for his embellishments about the Dark Lord's return to Mordor.'
'Don't you see?'
'It was the victory of Durin's Folk in the North that condemned you to the dungeons of Barad-dûr.'
'You have Gimli, his kin, and his allies to thank for your torments, Váskmun.'
'Then take it.'
'You won't get far, Váskmun. Your precious Manthríf will still be mine in the end.'
'[placeholder], I have heard you and Gimli have shared many adventures in your time beyond Mordor....'
'Nay, to change the very fate of Drása's Folk!'
Instance: A House Forged Anew
'My King! What has happened? Are you all right?'
'A Dwarf-ring? One of the Rings of Power?! For what did my friends and allies toil if not to rid the world of such things?'
'No good can come of this, King Váskmun.'
'And what happened after that?'
'And here is [placeholder], the brave Stout-axe who returned to Mordor and freed me from the dungeons of Barad-dûr!'
'At Dol Guldur in the Greenwood of old dwelt the Necromancer, a sorcerer of terrible might.'
'But in truth, the Necromancer was none other than the Dark Lord himself!'
'And once it is, your wretched people will be brought to heel once more!'
'So fearful was he, it is said, of the triumph of Durin's Folk that he fled back to Mordor!'
'Do what you will and begone from my sight!'
'Back here, I suppose...'
'What trickery is this?! It must be there! It was promised!'
'Fool of a dwarf! If I possessed it, what use would I have for you or your kind?'
'And so too do we shed the name of Drása himself, for this day we are born again!'
King Váskmun pulls his key from its chain and opens the mithril-wrought lockbox...
'The Stout-axes... the Khirvísa... those dwarves are dead and gone!'
'I see. You keep strange company, my friend. Ah, but I mean you no offence!'
'Offer this \qFellowship\q my truest thanks! Many were the evils visited upon us by the Dark Lord, and at last they are repaid!'
'We know well of the final siege at the gates of Mordor, but what of the battles that came before?'
'I am curious, [placeholder]. After all your efforts to escape your own servitude, how did your adventures lead you back to Mordor?'
'Spakorth, Gimli, [placeholder]....'
'You speak only lies, Zôreth! In truth, you abhor us. We are nothing to you but a means to an end!'
'From out of the dungeons of Barad-dûr, I have carried a key wrought of mithril. A key to change the fate of the Stout-axes.'
'Surrender Manthríf and I will spare you for your crimes against us!'
'You see, it is with this key that I might once again wield the Dwarf-ring, Manthríf!'
'Enough of your lies! Manthríf is mine!'
'My King?'
'Nonsense! It brought my people good fortune and wealth for many years.'
'Bah! Sauron is dead and gone! What use could he have for it now?'
'Zôreth has deceived you all! Spakorth was taken by one of her spirits!'
'I shall hear no more on -- Spakorth, what troubles you? You look unwell!'
'Bind Spakorth to one of the pillars and watch him! He is no friend of mine -- not anymore!'
'Eitur, Gimli, [placeholder] -- come with me! Zôreth shall pay for her treachery!'
'Zôreth!'
'I hereby demand the freedom of my people and the return of Manthríf, our ancestral Ring of Power.'
'It is ours by right!'
'It is magnificent, Sversting! I shall wield it well!'
'Do you think me a fool? You speak only lies, Zôreth!'
'I will hear no more of this!'
'Free my people, surrender Manthríf, and I will spare you!'
'If you will not, your life ends. THAT is the bargain!'
'It... is empty!'
'Come! As for you all, be merry and celebrate the days ahead for our people!'
'What have you done with it, Zôreth?!'
'Enough of your lies! Manthríf is mine!'
'It was not meant for you, dwarf! King or not!'
'Your people are free, King Váskmun, and Zôreth is defeated.'
'What you seek will not be yours!'
'Is that not enough?'
'The Mistress beckons...'
'Don't you see? It was the victory of Gimli's people that condemned you to the dungeons of Barad-dûr!'
'Your dwarf friend told an interesting tale, Váskmun, and one that I know well.'
'Will you now?'
'Then take it! You won't get far before the Order finds you, and it'll still be mine in the end!'
'Come, take it!'
'What trickery is this?! I swear I knew nothing of this deception!'
'Fool of a dwarf! I do not have the Ring!'
'So this is what the years of wearing the Dwarf-ring in the dungeons did to you? Oh yes, I know about that!'
'You shall destroy your own people, Váskmun! Even I could not be so cruel....'
'Skorgrím.... Did these Dourhands truly sense no danger in serving one who claimed to have returned from death?'
'A dwarf in form, but no will of his own. No, no good comes from having spirits about!'
'Hear my words!'
'As for the lost halls of Khazad-dûm, I hope they do not remain darkened. Gimli, may your people's expedition soon reclaim them!'
'Today I am honoured to welcome two warriors of renown to Lûghash!'
'If not Khazad-dûm, where now do your folk dwell, Gimli?'
'Here is Gimli, son of Glóin, dwarf of Durin's Folk! He has journeyed from far-off lands to explore the realm of Mordor!'
'These Kingdoms of Men sound a sight to behold! And to stand against so many foes... a wonder!'
'And here is [placeholder], the brave [placeholder] who aided my escape from the Dark Tower!'
'Hah! As any dwarf would hope!'
'[placeholder], I have heard you and Gimli have shared many adventures....'
'And by the time the day was ended, I slew twice as many on the fields of Gondor!'
'Ah, but have you met any other dwarves beyond those of Durin's Folk in your adventures? Do any other Dwarf-kingdoms remain?'
'I am curious, [placeholder]. How did your adventures lead you to Mordor?'
